Award.AwardTitle: ICES: Small: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Roles of Intermediaries in Matching Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Market design--economic engineering--has been successful in the redesign of real-world "two-sided matching markets," including the matching of doctors to residencies and the assignment of students to schools. A recent and growing literature has shown that the methods and results of two-sided matching theory extend to substantially more general settings, including "trading networks" in which agents negotiate over contracts.

Unlike two-sided matching markets, trading networks feature intermediaries, agents who both buy and sell in the market. These intermediaries may be intermediate producers (as in most economic models of supply chains) or may simply facilitate trade (e.g., through provision of information). Although the presence of intermediaries is the defining distinction between the matching-in-networks model and the previous two-sided frameworks, the analysis of intermediaries in these matching models has been limited.

This research will further our understanding of the behavior and impact of market intermediaries. Theoretical work using the matching-in-networks framework will be supplemented with detailed empirical analyses using plant-level microdata on production networks, in order to gain insight into the magnitudes of intermediaries' effects on welfare. Simulated counterfactual models will be developed when theory does not provide sharp predictions.

This work will inform and support new applications of market design approaches to real-world intermediated matching markets. One focus will be understanding how "local" perturbations (e.g., intermediary entrance and exit) affect the "global" structure of networks; another will be the identification and reduction of rent seeking by intermediaries.

In addition to enabling novel work in applied market design, this research will promote joint work between computer scientists and economists working in the theory and practice of market design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Chicago portion of this joint grant with Northwestern University (PI: Nicole Immorlica) has supported co-PI Eric Budish’s research on high
frequency trading and financial market design. This research argues
that there is a simple structural flaw in the design of modern
financial markets – continuous ­time trading – and proposes as an
alternative frequent batch auctions: uniform­-price double auctions
conducted at frequent but discrete time intervals, e.g., every 0.1
seconds or potentially even faster. That is, instead of processing
trade requests in continuous time in serial, financial markets should
process trade requests in discrete time in a batch. The distinction
between serial and batch processing is of course a familiar one to
computer scientists, as is the idea that computers don’t really run in
continuous time but in discrete time.

The grant also supported the work of co-PI Ali Hortacsu, who has explored the design of auctions for Treasury securities and the structure of interbank credit networks. These are both extremely large markets: the U.S. Treasury auctions trillions of government debt securities every year, and the volume of interbank lending is enormous. Moreover, linkages in the interbank credit market is thought to be a major contributor to systemic risk, the quantification of which is only possible through empirical measurement of theoretically important parameters.

The grant's support for Scott Kominers helped develop new economics and computer science foundations for matching market design. Kominers generalized tools and techniques of classical matching theory to network contexts. He also clarified the relationship between matching, auction, and exchange mechanisms, and determined exactly when those mechanisms can be used. His research introduces a new class of matching models that can be used in the design of diversity programs and rationing systems. He also uncovered linkages between strategy-proofness in matching markets and efficient ex ante investment incentives. These results were used to improve school choice and inspector allocation in Boston, as well as in other matching and resource allocation systems worldwide. Additionally, the results have informed the design of real-world intellectual property marketplaces.
